org.placeName: Western District of Washington Northern Division

div1.p: STATE OF WASHINGTON COUNTY OF KING ))) SS:

Bhagat Singh, being first duly sworn, deposes and says; that he was employed as a government immigration interpreter at Manila by the examination officials to interperate at the time when more than half of the seventy-three aliens who are now detained and whose cases are before the Federal Court were examined, and he knows that these men were properly examined by the immigration officers and given the same examination as is given at the ports of the United States proper and at Seattle and he knows that they came into Manila in a lawful manner and were held at the border for examination and were duly examined by the government and were passed and permitted to land at Manila and were given certificates similar to certificate "A" attached to the other affidavit, showing their lawful admission and their proper examination and the fact that they had passed said examination to the satisfaction of the government's immigration inspectors, and this affiant attaches hereto letters from the acting chief of the immigration division and two different inspectors of immigration at Manila, showing that he did serve as said interpreter and showing that he is qualified to testify as to the proper admission of all of those detained who had been in Manila for a period of less than one year. This affiant also knows from his familiarity with the seventy-three Hindoos and from his education and his ability to both
understand the government requirements and to talk ot his countrymen that the seventy-three men detained are all in the same position to the half of the men for whom he interpreted as a representative of the government. This affiant further knows that it is the custom of the government inspectors in examining both at Manila and Seattle, to examin the passports and certificates which all of these seventy-three men held and their other papers and after examination and surrender to the government by the aliens of said papers, that the government makes it a practice to return these papers to the alien for the reason that they would be too bulky and would take up to much file space.
Bhagat Singh
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 27th day of August, 1913.
Herbert W. Meyers
Notary Public in and for the state of Washington residing at Seattle.
To whom it may concern: This is to certify that the bearer, Bhagat Singh, has acted as interpreter in this Office at various times, and his services have always been satisfactory.
William Brad Acting Chief, Immigration Division.
BUREAU OF CUSTOMS Manila

To whom it may concern, The bearer of this, Bagat Singh, East Indian, has been employed at this office at various times as interperter, and his services have always been very satisfactory. From my knowledge of him he is honest and gentlemanly.
His English is far above the East Indian of his class.
I wholeheartidly recommend him to any one desiring the services of such a man
PyMy gatt Insp. of Immigration
BUREAU OF CUSTOMS MANILA, P.I.
TO WHOM IT MAY CONCERN: This is to certify that Bhagat Singh has been employed in the Custom House at Manila, P.I. as East Indian Interpreter since October 1912 and has always been satisfactory.
I wish to recommend him to anyone needing his services as he is an honest, sober and industrious man.
Respectfully, JE Nouthers Immigration Inspector.
